repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
See #27192 for the context and why this is needed.

Summary: Separate the lint job (`make lintdoc`) to validate runtime/doc,
it is no longer as a part of functionaltest (help_spec).

### Build (cmake) and CI:

- `make lintdoc`: validate vimdoc files and test-generate HTML docs.
  CI will run this as a part of the "docs" workflow.

- `scripts/lintdoc.lua` is added as an entry point (executable script)
  for validating vimdoc files.

### scripts/gen_help_html.lua:

- Move the tests for validating docs and generating HTMLs from
  `help_spec.lua` to `gen_help_html`. Added:
  - `gen_help_html.run_validate()`.
  - `gen_help_html.test_gen()`.

- Do not hard-code `help_dir` to `build/runtime/doc`, but resolve from
  `$VIMRUNTIME`. Therefore, the `make lintdoc` job will check doc files
  on `./runtime/doc`, not on `./build/runtime/doc`.

- Add type annotations for gen_help_html.

comment_data.body: @dundargoc I wasn't sure which build target this should depend on, so as to ensure that `build/runtime/doc/*.txt` is up-to-date and identical with the source (`./runtime/doc/*.txt`). On CI jobs, it might be fine because it will do a clean build from scratch; but when it comes to a local dev environment, changes on `./runtime/doc/*.txt` are NOT correctly reflected to `build/runtime/doc/*.txt`, so the validation result may not be consistent. Maybe the previous functionaltest (`help_spec`) also had the same issue.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,3 +953,12 @@ add_custom_target(doc-eval DEPENDS ${GEN_EVAL_TOUCH})
 add_custom_target(doc-vim DEPENDS ${VIMDOC_FILES})
 add_custom_target(doc)
 add_dependencies(doc doc-vim doc-eval)
+
+add_custom_target(doctest
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -es --clean +'helptags ALL'
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_validate\(\)\"
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_gen\(\)\"
+  DEPENDS
+    doc

comment_data.body: No, you can't do this. `nvim` isn't a file, you can't depend on it. Dependencies between targets must use `add_dependencies`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,3 +953,10 @@ add_custom_target(doc-eval DEPENDS ${GEN_EVAL_TOUCH})
 add_custom_target(doc-vim DEPENDS ${VIMDOC_FILES})
 add_custom_target(doc)
 add_dependencies(doc doc-vim doc-eval)
+
+add_custom_target(lintdoc
+  COMMAND ${CMAKE_COMMAND} -E env "VIMRUNTIME=${NVIM_RUNTIME_DIR}"
+    $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> --clean -l 'scripts/lintdoc.lua'
+  WORKING_DIRECTORY ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}
+  DEPENDS nvim

comment_data.body:

```

comment_data.body:
This has been resolved:

- Confirmed that the previous `help_spec` test was reading `./build/runtime/doc`, which can be out of sync with the source doc files (`./runtime/doc`).
- Changed `lintdoc` job to *always* read and validate `./runtime/doc`; the `lintdoc.lua` script itself might read different helpdir if different `$VIMRUNTIME` is provided.
- Duplicate `build/runtime/doc` might need to be cleaned up in the future.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,3 +953,12 @@ add_custom_target(doc-eval DEPENDS ${GEN_EVAL_TOUCH})
 add_custom_target(doc-vim DEPENDS ${VIMDOC_FILES})
 add_custom_target(doc)
 add_dependencies(doc doc-vim doc-eval)
+
+add_custom_target(doctest
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -es --clean +'helptags ALL'
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_validate\(\)\"
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_gen\(\)\"
+  DEPENDS
+    doc

comment_data.body: Is this still needed? If so I can take a look at the build system to fix it instead of trying to work around it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env -S nvim -l
+
+-- Validate vimdoc files on $VIMRUNTIME/doc, and test generating HTML docs.
+-- Checks for duplicate/missing tags, parse errors, and invalid links/urls/spellings.
+-- See also `make lintdoc`.
+--
+-- Usage:
+--   $ nvim -l scripts/lintdoc.lua
+--   $ make lintdoc
+
+print('Running lintdoc ...')
+
+-- gen_help_html requires :helptags to be generated on $VIMRUNTIME/doc
+-- :helptags checks for duplicate tags.
+vim.cmd [[ helptags ALL ]]

comment_data.body: Yes, please---that has bitten people before.

comment_data.body:
Good point. `:helptags` should've already been done in `make doc`; `lintdoc` should *fail* instead if helptags were not generated.

Also, when there is a duplicated tag, `:helptags` will raise errors there are duplicates an error message is given. This could be thought of as a part of *validating docs* but failing early (in `make doc`) would also make sense.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env -S nvim -l
+
+-- Validate vimdoc files on $VIMRUNTIME/doc, and test generating HTML docs.
+-- Checks for duplicate/missing tags, parse errors, and invalid links/urls/spellings.
+-- See also `make lintdoc`.
+--
+-- Usage:
+--   $ nvim -l scripts/lintdoc.lua
+--   $ make lintdoc
+
+print('Running lintdoc ...')
+
+-- gen_help_html requires :helptags to be generated on $VIMRUNTIME/doc
+-- :helptags checks for duplicate tags.
+vim.cmd [[ helptags ALL ]]

comment_data.body: @justinmk As a follow-up after this PR, we might be getting rid of (the duplicate) `build/runtime/doc` out of the build process. Do you see any unforseen problems here? Where else is it being used? (/cc @dundargoc)

@@ -953,3 +953,12 @@ add_custom_target(doc-eval DEPENDS ${GEN_EVAL_TOUCH})

 add_custom_target(doc)
 add_dependencies(doc doc-vim doc-eval)
+
+add_custom_target(doctest
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -es --clean +'helptags ALL'
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_validate\(\)\"
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_gen\(\)\"
+  DEPENDS
+    doc

@@ -2,32 +2,38 @@
 --
 -- NOTE: :helptags checks for duplicate tags, whereas this script checks _links_ (to tags).
 --
+-- USAGE (For CI/local testing purposes): Simply `make lintdoc` or `scripts/lintdoc.lua`, which
+-- basically does the following:
+--   1. :helptags ALL
+--   2. nvim -V1 -es +"lua require('scripts.gen_help_html').run_validate()" +q
+--   3. nvim -V1 -es +"lua require('scripts.gen_help_html').test_gen()" +q
+--
 -- USAGE (GENERATE HTML):
---   1. Run `make helptags` first; this script depends on vim.fn.taglist().
---   2. nvim -V1 -es --clean +"lua require('scripts.gen_help_html').gen('./build/runtime/doc/', 'target/dir/')"
+--   1. `:helptags ALL` first; this script depends on vim.fn.taglist().
+--   2. nvim -V1 -es --clean +"lua require('scripts.gen_help_html').gen('$VIMRUNTIME/doc', 'target/dir/')" +q

```

comment_data.body: This is fine for now, but I have an upcoming PR which will explore the idea of `test/lint/`, so lint jobs will just be tests, instead of having to write ad-hoc scripts for each lint task.
I see. When some files had invalid tags or other errors, I found it saying "generated (0 errors)", but I'm fine with reverting it.

comment_data.body:
The reason why I put this is to remove unnecessary message when `-V1` is used:

```diff
  nvim -V1 -es -c 'lua error()'
 Error detected while processing command line:
 E5108: Error executing lua [NULL]
-Entering Ex mode.  Type "visual" to go to Normal mode.
-:%
```
(note: it preserves the exit code well depending on whether error `:message` was emitted) So let's keep it?

comment_data.body:
> As a follow-up after this PR, we might be getting rid of (the duplicate) `build/runtime/doc` out of the build process. Do you see any unforseen problems here?

No objection. I only was using it because it worked better than previous things I tried.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,3 +953,12 @@ add_custom_target(doc-eval DEPENDS ${GEN_EVAL_TOUCH})
 add_custom_target(doc-vim DEPENDS ${VIMDOC_FILES})
 add_custom_target(doc)
 add_dependencies(doc doc-vim doc-eval)
+
+add_custom_target(doctest
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -es --clean +'helptags ALL'
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_validate\(\)\"
+  COMMAND $<TARGET_FILE:nvim_bin> -V1 -es --clean +\"lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_gen\(\)\"
+  DEPENDS
+    doc

comment_regular_data.body:
Some thoughts:

- When `gen_help_html` was written in #11967, generating the entire HTML docs (129 in total) is said to be 10x slower (~30 seconds) than doing validation only, according to the comments written.
  - But in my local environments (macbook M1 Pro) it now only takes 11 seconds. Maybe treesitter has improved? :P Running validation only takes 7 seconds. So it feels like we could run just both of them in full?
  - On Github CI things might run slower. But functional/unit tests would take *much* longer to run, so doc generation shouldn't be a bottleneck anyway...?

- "A straight-up nvim -l shebang script would be simple" (#27192)
  - True, rather than `lua require'scripts.gen_help_html'.test_validate()` blah. It will also make simpler the CMakefile and the command line to type locally. Then we'll have *another* script which is just an entrypoint to `gen_help_html`. ~~Something to decide.~~ 
  - Resolution: Accepted, see `scripts/lintdoc.lua`.

- Need to be mindful of which `doc/` directory is to be read (`runtime/doc` v.s. `build/runtime/doc`).
  - Problem: there are **two** runtime/doc folder which is quite confusing to me, and we need to make it clear `lintdoc` (or functionaltest, etc.) picks up which VIMRUNTIME directory. These two help directories (`./runtime/doc` v.s. `./build/runtime/doc`) can go easily out-of-sync and result in an inconsistent validation result.
  - Status: For now I've changed it to be applied on the "source" directory (`./runtime/doc`) only; it was previously only on `./build/runtime/doc`. ~~Need revisit this again.~~
  - Resolution: See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27227#discussion_r1468636386

Actually, my point was to _not_ have this be a "test" but a "lint". So I would prefer this to be a `lintdoc` target and added to `make lint`. (If it's possible, due to the fact that it needs a built nvim + runtime.)

Actually actually, I changed my mind: It probably fits best in the [docs workflow](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/.github/workflows/docs.yml), which already calls `make doc`. So I think the easiest thing would be to include the validation in that target?

> It probably fits best in the docs workflow, which already calls make doc. So I think the easiest thing would be to include the validation in that target?

Yes, I agree --- this PR is also written in that manner, validating docs runs as a part of the "docs" workflow (right after `make doc`). CI's `lint` job runs each of `lintc`, `stylua` separately so "lintdoc" won't run in the `lint` job.

I *actually* changed the target name to `lintdoc`, and could make it as a dependency to the `lint` target. (To be picky, `make lintdoc` being a part of `make lint` but not running in the "`lint`" CI job can be a bit confusing)

We could `make doc` run both of (1) doc generation and (2) doc validation, but when I initially wrote this I chose to separate these two -- because validation is often slower; and it's similar to `make` and `make {functional,unit}test` being separate.
I think keeping these two separate makes sense.
For now I renamed it to `lintdoc` from `doctest`, but we can easily choose and go either way (it's just a matter of naming). Leaving undecided for the time being.

labels.name: build

labels.description: automation for build, test, and release

title: build(docs): separate lint job `make lintdoc` to validate vimdoc files
